title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The term "hazardous agents" refers to both dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Secretary must also consult with states, including their public health officers and attorneys general. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act defines "hazardous agents" as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. A dangerous biological agent is one listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 and not exempted from regulations. Dangerous chemicals are those listed under the Act within 45 days of its enactment. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of chemicals known or anticipated to cause serious harm to human health, including those intended for malicious use. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents, with specific provisions for each agent, prioritizing them within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents, prioritizing them within 45 days of enactment. The protocols will ensure uniform application in public health emergencies and coordination with emergency response personnel. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents within 45 days of enactment to ensure uniform application in public health emergencies. This includes providing medically appropriate information, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and responding differently based on the nature of the emergency. The protocols will be periodically reviewed and revised as needed. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents within 45 days of enactment to ensure uniform application in public health emergencies. Development exemptions may be granted if existing protocols meet requirements. Authorization of appropriations is provided for implementation. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006, in addition to other authorizations available for the same purpose.
